content.statement: proc-001-femoral-exposure is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding proc-001-femoral-exposure helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of proc-001-femoral-exposure include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of proc-001-femoral-exposure.

definitions_glossary.common_femoral_artery: The external iliac artery after it passes under the inguinal ligament
definitions_glossary.superficial_femoral_artery: The continuation of the CFA after the profunda takeoff, runs in the adductor canal
definitions_glossary.profunda_femoris: Deep femoral artery, major blood supply to the thigh muscles
definitions_glossary.femoral_sheath: Fascial compartment containing femoral artery, vein, and canal
definitions_glossary.inguinal_ligament: Ligament from ASIS to pubic tubercle, key landmark for femoral exposure

indications: Endovascular access for aortic and iliac interventions
contraindications: Active groin infection (relative - may need alternative exposure)
Hostile groin (prior radiation, multiple surgeries - consider alternative access)
Femoral artery occlusion (for endovascular access - use alternative site)

technique.positioning: Supine with mild external rotation and abduction of the leg

incision_options.vertical: Easier extension, standard for most cases
incision_options.oblique: May heal better in obese patients, follows skin lines

key_structures.femoral_vein: Lies medial to artery, be careful with retraction
key_structures.femoral_nerve: Lateral to artery, outside femoral sheath
key_structures.lateral_circumflex_vein: Crosses anterior to artery at bifurcation, may need ligation
key_structures.lymphatics: Multiple superficial nodes, preserve when possible

steps: Identify femoral pulse (or use ultrasound if absent)
Make incision 2 fingerbreadths below inguinal ligament
Divide skin, subcutaneous tissue, Scarpa's fascia
Identify femoral sheath and incise longitudinally
Place vessel loops on all three vessels
Extend dissection as needed for planned procedure

complications.management: Antibiotics, drainage, sartorius flap coverage if deep

complications.prevention: Careful medial dissection, identify vein early
Stay medial to sartorius, avoid lateral retraction
complications.management: Usually traction injury, recovers over months

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the common, superficial, and profunda femoral arteries through a groin incision for vascular procedures

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of the femoral triangle and femoral vessels
Perform surgical exposure of the common, superficial, and profunda femoral arteries
Identify and protect adjacent structures (vein, nerve, lymphatics)
Recognize and manage complications of femoral exposure
clinical_pearls: The profunda femoris is the key vessel - always ensure it's preserved in occlusive disease
External rotation of the leg brings the femoral artery more anterior and superficial
If you can't feel a pulse, use ultrasound to mark the artery before incision
The lateral circumflex vein crosses the field at the bifurcation - anticipate and ligate
Lymphatic complications are the most common - handle tissues gently

medicalCode.description: Inspection of femoral artery, open approach
